stem: A 9-month-old infant has sudden, episodic abdominal pain where he draws his knees to his chest. He passed a 'currant jelly' stool. Complete the bowtie to guide care.

actions.text: Prepare for an air or barium enema
Offer clear liquids until pain subsides
Manually reduce the mass via abdominal palpation
Initiate IV fluids and maintain NPO

rationale.correct: Telescoping bowel = Intussusception. Currant jelly stool (blood+mucus) is the classic sign. Air/Barium enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic (reduces the telescoping). Monitoring stool is key; if a normal brown stool occurs, it may have resolved spontaneously.
rationale.incorrect: The child must stay NPO until resolution to prevent further distension/complications. Manual reduction is not safe. Head circumference is irrelevant.
clinicalPearls: The presence of a normal brown stool means the intussusception has likely reduced; notify the provider immediately as surgery/enema may be cancelled.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the abdomen becomes rigid or the fever spikes, it suggests perforation/peritonitis, and the enema should NOT be performed.

mnemonic.title: INTUSSUSCEPTION
mnemonic.expansion:
I = Intussusception

Key Actions: Prepare for an air or barium enema; Initiate IV fluids and maintain NPO
Key Monitoring: Characteristics of stool (Consistency/Color); Signs of bowel perforation (Rigidity/Fever)

reviewUnits.heading: Intussusception â€” Pathophysiology & Recognition
reviewUnits.body: Telescoping bowel = Intussusception. Currant jelly stool (blood+mucus) is the classic sign. Air/Barium enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic (reduces the telescoping). Monitoring stool is key; if a normal brown stool occurs, it may have resolved spontaneously. The presence of a normal brown stool means the intussusception has likely reduced; notify the provider immediately as surgery/enema may be cancelled.

reviewUnits.heading: Testing Trap â€” Rigid abdomen
reviewUnits.body: If the abdomen becomes rigid or the fever spikes, it suggests perforation/peritonitis, and the enema should NOT be performed.

reviewUnits.heading: Priority Interventions for Intussusception
reviewUnits.body: The priority nursing interventions are: Prepare for an air or barium enema; Initiate IV fluids and maintain NPO. Monitor: Characteristics of stool (Consistency/Color); Signs of bowel perforation (Rigidity/Fever). The child must stay NPO until resolution to prevent further distension/complications. Manual reduction is not safe. Head circumference is irrelevant.
